instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_POWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_POWRGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS_POWRGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message: Hello! Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here with quarter fan spin. Already verified all current sensing resistors around ISL area, replaced ISL, replaced clock chip but no luck. I get steady 3.3V on L7220 and steady 12.54V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Get a sparkle of 5V on L7260 when quarter fan spin. Already verified all traces around ISL and all look good. There was no corrosion at all on this board! I'm lost, because this is the first quarter fan spin that is giving me so much trouble!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 48951"]<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/3 ok? Any history? [/QUOTE]

Both read fine! No liquid history... Costumer said it was working and died of a sudden... I think this machine had been worked on before he bought it(he bought it used but working), but cannot be sure because it had no oxidation points nor solder marks on it... The board looked very clean!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message:
Check if all big coils pulse at least.
<SIGNAL>AL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing?
Also try to start in SMC bypass mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message: I do get pulses on all coils except L7510, 7520 and 7550. Cannot start in SMC bypass. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_POWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses too when quarter fan spin!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 48966"]Check all voltages from pages 71/72.[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>ENET_SR_LX</SIGNAL> - pulses when quarter fan to around 2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS_LDO</SIGNAL> - 1.05V steady
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_REG</SIGNAL> - Pulses around 0.4V when quarter fan
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0_REG</SIGNAL> - Pulses around 2.7V when quarter fan
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_LDO</SIGNAL> . Pulses around 0.4V when quarter fan
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_FET</SIGNAL> - Pulses to 3.3V when quarter fan spin, around 0.7V when the board shuts down after quarter fan
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_FET</SIGNAL> - Pulses to 3.3V when quarter fan, around 0.4V when the board shuts down after quarter fan
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_FET</SIGNAL> - Pulses around 3.3V when quarter fan, 0V when the board shuts down
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> - 0V, Pulses to 3.3V when quarter fan
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> - Steady 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> - Steady 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> - Pulses around 5V when quarter fan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0_REG</SIGNAL> - Pulses around 2.7V when quarter fan"
Are you sure about this?
Check it again.
Is normal to get lower value, because of short pulse; but not almost two times higher voltage...
If use o-scope, you can catch the real values on all points.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message: I tried replacing <CHIP>U7770</CHIP> which creates <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0_REG</SIGNAL> and still same readings. That's odd!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message:
Can't be multimeter issue, as the other points do not have same problem.
Remove <CHIP>U7770</CHIP> and check again.
See if there still pulses the same...

BTW, do NOT quote an entire post; maintain forum aesthetic...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message: No pulsing and no quarter fan without <CHIP>U7770</CHIP>. The board is dead without it!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message: Try other chip; looks like higher voltage passed through it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message: Replaced it twice, same results. Also replaced <CAPACITOR>C7773</CAPACITOR> just in case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message:
Try replacing L7770.
Donor board if possible.
If not, choose one with same marking; 10R, I suppose...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message: Replaced the coil with one from donor board. Same behavior and voltages..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Quarter Fan Spin
threads.message:
Pufff, really strange; nothing more suspect on that circuit.
Could be PCH/CPU, or just a f***g resistor.
Check 25MHz presence at pin 9/<CHIP>U2600</CHIP>.
Try new BIOS, just in case...
